laboratory_examinations.findings: GH levels were very low (1.0 ng/mL) and failed to reach normal levels after stimulation (peak GH, 1.9 ng/mL; normal >7 ng/mL).
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: At 10.7 yr, GH levels increased slightly (2.8 ng/mL) but were still low. By 14.1 yr, GH levels decreased further to 0.2 ng/mL.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Basal cortisol levels were normal and rose adequately in response to hypoglycemia.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Cortisol response to hypoglycemia remained normal up to age 14.1 yr.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Basal TSH levels were normal but displayed a blunted response to stimulation.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: TSH deficiencies continued to be documented at ages 10.7 and 14.1 yr.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Basal PRL levels were normal but showed a blunted response to TRH stimulation.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: PRL deficiencies were noted at ages 10.7 and 14.1 yr.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Gonadotropin levels were below the limit of detection before and after GnRH administration.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Gonadotropin deficiencies persisted at age 14.1 yr.

laboratory_examinations.findings: GH, TSH, PRL, LH, FSH levels were measured, with GH showing very low levels.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Repeated evaluations exhibited persistent deficiencies in GH, TSH, PRL, and gonadotropins.
